The role a bard plays in service to their college varies greatly. Bards dedicated to justice may uplift noble causes with song and skill. Those who venerate knowledge may seek rare tomes or artifacts that have been lost for centuries. Others may serve as dirgesingers, spreading sorrow and grief.

Some bards may have started as choir singers in temples before seeking adventure. Some may act as agents or spies. Others may seek out new converts for their faith. Whatever their reasons or motives, bards in Colleges of Worship have heeded the call of their god, much like a paladin or cleric.

subclassFeature.name: Call of the Faithful
entries: At the 3rd level, you gain proficiency in one of the following skills of your choice: {@skill Arcana}, {@skill History}, {@skill Medicine}, or {@skill Religion}. You can also use a {@item holy symbol|PHB} as a spellcasting focus for your bard spells.

subclassFeature.name: Divine Inspiration
entries: At the 3rd level, your faith has granted you the following abilities.

entries.name: Elegy for the Departed
entries: You can expend a use of your Bardic Inspiration to sing a lamenting elegy. As an action, choose one or more undead creatures within 30 feet of you, up to your proficiency bonus. Each undead must make a Wisdom saving throw. On a failed save, a creature takes radiant damage equal to a roll of your Bardic Inspiration die + your Charisma modifier, and its speed is reduced to 0 until the start of your next turn. On a successful save, a creature takes half as much damage and its speed is not reduced.

entries.name: Sacred Hymn
entries: You can expend a use of your Bardic Inspiration to intone sacred words of your deity. As an action, choose a number of creatures that can hear you within 60 feet of you up to your proficiency bonus regain hit points equal to a roll of your Bardic Inspiration die + your Charisma modifier (minimum +1).

subclassFeature.name: Holy Magic
entries: At 6th level, you learn additional spells from your deity. Choose one Divine DOmain from the Cleric class, appropriate for your deity. You learn two spells of your choice from the list of Domain Spells, and one cantrip of your choice from the {@filter cleric spell list|spells|level=0|class=cleric} Each spell you choose must be of a level you can cast, as shown on the Bard table. The chosen spells count as bard spells for you, but they don't count against the number of bard spells you know.

Whenever you reach a level in this class that grants the Ability Score Improvement feature, you can replace one spell you learned from this feature with another spell from the chosen Domain Spell list.

subclassFeature.name: Deus ex Machina
entries: Starting at 14th level, you can implore your god to directly intervene in the affairs of mortals. Immediately after a creature uses your Bardic Inspiration on an attack roll, ability check, or saving throw and fails, you can use your reaction to allow divine energy to flow through you, granting the creature a +10 bonus to the roll.
Once you use this feature, you can't use it again until you finish a long rest.

subclassFeature.name: Circle of the Predator
entries: While some druid circles are passive protectors of the natural world, preserving their charges as threats arise, druids of the predator's circle take on the mantle of actively hunting unnatural forces. Druids of this circle might come from shattered groves, where a great unnatural beast has befouled the land, and the druid swears to stop evils like the one they faced from destroying anymore of the natural world.

These druids combine a primal ferocity with their connection to the magics of the natural world to become an indomitable predator. They see themselves as protectors of the world, and hunters of any force that would dare to throw it into imbalance.
The magic of the wild runs through the blood of these druids, and by tooth and claw they will defend it.

subclassFeature.name: Savage Attacker
entries: Starting at 2nd level, your attunement to nature greatly enhances your senses. You gain the following benefits.

items: You know the {@spell primal savagery|XGE} cantrip. If you already know this cantrip, you learn a different cantrip of your choice from the druid spell list. The cantrip doesn't count against your number of cantrips known.
You gain {@sense darkvision} out to a range of 60 feet. If you already have this sense, its range increases by 30 feet.
You gain proficiency with one of the following skills: {@skill Nature}, {@skill Perception}, {@skill Stealth}, or {@skill Survival}.

subclassFeature.name: Primal Form
entries: Also at 2nd level, you can invoke an ancient magic to transform your body, becoming more like the strong, instinctive beasts you choose as your company. As a bonus action, you can expend a use of your Wild Shape feature to take on a primal form, rather than transforming into a beast.

While in your primal form, your body grows bestial features, like excessive fur or monstrous scales, though you retain your normal shape. The form lasts for 1 minute, and it ends early if you dismiss it on your turn (no action required) or become {@condition incapacitated}.
While in your primal form, you gain the following benefits:

items: Your walking speed increases by 10 feet.
At the start of each of your turns, you gain temporary hit points equal to half your druid level, rounded down.
You can use your Wisdom modifier, instead of Strength or Dexterity modifier, for the attack and damage rolls of your melee attacks.
Your attacks count as magical for the purpose of overcoming resistance and immunity to nonmagical attacks and damage.

subclassFeature.name: Predator's Strike
entries: Starting at 6th level, your hunger for blood rivals that of the fiercest of carnivores. When you use your action to cast a cantrip, you can make one melee attack as a bonus action.

subclassFeature.name: Instinctual Reflexes
entries: At 10th level, your heightened primal senses can warn you of an incoming attack. While you are in your Primal Form and an attacker that you can see within 30 feet of you hits you with an attack, you can use your reaction to impose disadvantage on the attack roll.
When you dodge in this way, you may also move up to 5 feet to any unoccupied space. This movement does not provoke opportunity attacks.

subclassFeature.name: Apex Predator
entries: Starting at 14th level, you've ascended to the top of the food chain, and few creatures are able to withstand your incredible power. When you take damage from a creature that is within 5 feet of you, you can use your reaction to make a melee attack against that creature.
This feature can be used in your normal form, primal form, or Wild Shape.

subclassFeature.name: Circle of Seeds
entries: The druids who belong to the Circle of Seeds venerate plants and the beginning of life itself. They see plants as the purest expression of life, growth, and the natural world, whether they are vast grasslands, might forests, steamy jungles, or lone cacti. Such druids still view all life as equal, but they know that without plants, all life will eventually perish.

These druids regularly seek the wisdom of {@creature dryad|MM|dryads} and {@creature treant|MM|treants} and strive to protect the oldest trees and most vulnerable flora in the world from harm. As they journey the world, they often plant seeds where they are needed, revitalizing damaged wilderness and giving life to barren wastelands. In battle, these druids embody the tactics of plants, slowly taking control of the battlefield and establishing traps and hazards using plant magic.

subclassFeature.name: Circle Spells
entries: Your connection to the plants of the world enables you to easily cast botanical magic, granting you access to certain spells. At 2nd level, you learn the {@spell druidcraft} cantrip.

At 3rd, 5th, 7th, and 9th level you gain access to the spells listed for that level in the Circle of Seeds Spells table. Once you gain access to one of these spells, it is a druid spell for you, you always have it prepared, and it doesn't count against the number of spells you can prepare each day.

entries.caption: Circle of Seeds Spells
rows: {@spell aura of life}, {@spell guardian of nature|XGE}

subclassFeature.name: Plant Shape
entries: Starting at 2nd level, even in your beast form, you take on floral properties. While you are transformed by Wild Shape, you gain the following benefits:

items: Your hit point maximum increases by an amount equal to your druid level.
You are considered a type of plant instead of a beast.
You cannot be {@condition blinded} or {@condition deafened}.
You can ignore the verbal components of your druid spells.

If you remain motionless for 1 minute, you can reshape your body to become indistinguishable from a nonmagical plant. You can quickly revert your shape as a bonus action. The size of your Wild Shape form determines what type of plant you appear to be: a tree (Large or Huge), a large bush or tangle of vines (Medium), a shrub (Small), or a flower or fungus (Tiny).

entries: While in Wild Shape, your bestial body is made from leaves, vines, roots, and other plantlike material. It's obvious to an observer that you are not a normal animal.

subclassFeature.name: Photosynthesis
entries: At 6th level, your skin can absorb energy from sunlight, gaining a subtle green complexion. For each hour you spend in direct sunlight, you gain energy equal to your druid level.

As an action, you can draw power from the pool to restore a number of hit points to yourself, up to the maximum amount remaining in your pool. The maximum energy you can store is equal to 3 × your druid level, and the pool resets to zero when you finish a long rest.
Additionally, if you have been sunlight for at least one hour, you do not require food for 24 hours.

subclassFeature.name: Flowery Speech
entries: Also at 6th level, you gain the ability to communicate directly to the spirits of plants in the world. You can cast {@spell speak with plants} at will, without expending a spell slot.

subclassFeature.name: Garden Variety
entries: At 10th level, your body learns from the plantlife around you. When you use your Wild Shape, you may choose to gain one of the following benefits:

entries.name: Clinging Thorns
entries: You gain a climbing speed of 30 feet, and you can climb difficult surfaces, including upside down on ceilings, without needing to make an ability check.

entries.name: Expel Toxins
entries: You gain resistance to poison damage and immunity to the {@condition poisoned} condition.

entries.name: Grasping Vines
entries: Two slender, whiplike vines spring from your body. As a bonus action, you can direct one of these vines to lash out at a Large or smaller creature within 15 feet of you that you can see. That creature must succeed on a Dexterity saving throw or be pulled up to 15 feet directly toward you.

entries.name: Leaf Sense
entries: You gain {@sense blindsight} out to 15 feet.

entries.name: Thorn in Your Side
entries: Each of your attacks deals an additional {@dice 1d6} damage of the attack's type.

subclassFeature.name: Mighty Oak
entries: At 14th level, your plant form becomes covered in protective plates of ironwood—a material as heavy and strong as steel. While you are transformed by Wild Shape, you are resistant to bludgeoning, piercing, and slashing damage, and you gain a +1 bonus to your AC.

subclassFeature.name: Circle of Storms
entries: Druids of the Circle of Storms have communed, through ancient rituals, with the four winds (North, East, South, and West) and with the ancient progenitor of all storms, a magical tempst known as the primal storm. These druids teach that, just like the primal storm, nature is in constant flux, and that this change is a good thing. They anticipate the sudden arrival of a storm or danger at all times, and believe that wisdom involves knowing when to run with the wind and when to run against it.

Storm druids can often be found in tribal societies that live on open plains, on mountains, or along coasts. Some venerate a particular wind, such as the icy North Wind, or a type of storm, such as a monsoon or tornado. In battle, they buffet and manipulate their foes with wind and lightning. They invoke the power of the primal storm, rising off the earth to blast their enemies with all of the shocking fury of a thunderstorm.

subclassFeature.name: Circle Spells
entries: Your bond with the four winds and the primal storm grants you access to certain spells. At 2nd level, you learn the {@spell lightning lure|TCE} cantrip.

At 3rd, 5th, 7th, and 9th level you gain access to the spells listed for that level in the Circle of Storms Spells table. Once you gain access to one of these spells, it is a druid spell for you, you always have it prepared, and it doesn't count against the number of spells you can prepare each day.

subclassFeature.name: Call the Wind
entries: Starting at 2nd level, you can use your bonus action to buffet a creature with howling wind. Choose a target that you can see within 60 feet of you. It must succeed on a Strength saving throw against your spell save DC or be pushed 10 feet in a direction of your choice.
If you or the target are underground or indoors, the target only moves 5 feet.

subclassFeature.name: Storm Ascension
entries: At 2nd level, you gain the ability to embrace the power of the primal storm. As an action, you can expend a use of your Wild Shape feature to ascend as a storm, rather than transforming into a beast.
While this feature is active, you gain the following benefits:

items: You gain 4 temporary hit points for each level you have in this class.
You have a flying speed equal to your walking speed, and you can hover.

When a target fails its saving throw against your Call the Wind feature, it takes {@dice 1d6} thunder damage. This damage increases to {@dice 1d8} at 6th level, {@dice 1d10} at 10th level, and {@dice 1d12} at 14th level.

entries: These benefits last for 10 minutes, until you lose all these temporary hit points, or until you use your Wild Shape again.

subclassFeature.name: Inner Tempest
entries: Starting at 6th level, you gain resistance to lightning damage. Additionally while your Storm Ascension feature is active, you may add your Wisdom modifier to the damage you deal with any druid spell (minimum +1).

subclassFeature.name: Updraft
entries: At 10th level, your bond with the four winds enables you to call upon them at a moment's notice. While your Storm Ascension feature is active, your flying speed is no longer restricted to an altitude of 5 feet.

subclassFeature.name: Herald the Four Winds
entries: Starting at 14th level, while your Storm Ascension feature is active, you may cast the {@spell gust of wind} or {@spell warding wind|XGE} spells at will, without expending a spell slot or material components.

subclassFeature.name: Circle of the Tides
entries: Few natural forces exert as much influence over mortals as the waters of the world. Rain for crops, raging storms, and winding rivers all influence mortal folk throughout their lives. Druids of the Circle of the Tides monitor the relationship between civilization and the wild oceans, rivers, and ponds that give life. Tidal druids can often be found using the life-giving power of the waters to heal the sick, provide rest to the weary, and nurture the crops of common folk.

subclassFeature.name: Circle Spells
entries: Your connection to the flowing sea grants you access to certain spells. At 2nd level, you learn the {@spell shape water|XGE} cantrip.

At 3rd, 5th, 7th, and 9th level you gain access to the spells listed for that level in the Circle of the Tides Spells table. Once you gain access to one of these spells, it is a druid spell for you, you always have it prepared, and it doesn't count against the number of spells you can prepare each day.

subclassFeature.name: Child of the Sea
entries: At 2nd level, you can breathe both air and water, and you gain a swimming speed equal to your walking speed.

subclassFeature.name: Tidal Aura
entries: Beginning at 2nd level, you can channel the mystical power of the tides. As a bonus action, you can expend a use of your Wild Shape feature to exude a mystical watery force in a 15-foot radius. The area becomes difficult terrain for creatures that lack a swimming speed. You can choose one or more creatures that lack a swimming speed. You can choose one or more creatures up to your proficiency bonus to ignore this difficult terrain.

When you cast a spell of 1st-level or higher that restores hit points, you can restore additional hit points equal to your Wisdom modifier (minimum of 1 hit point) to one target of that spell within your Tidal Aura.
Your Tidal Aura lasts for 10 minutes, until you are {@condition incapacitated}, or until you use your Wild Shape again.

subclassFeature.name: Undertow
entries: Starting at 6th level, when you cast a spell that forces a creature within your Tidal Aura to make a Strength, Dexterity, or Constitution saving throw, you can use your bonus action to impose disadvantage on that creature's saving throw.
Once you use this feature, you can't use it again until you finish a long rest, unless you expend a spell slot of 2nd-level or higher to use it again.

subclassFeature.name: Waters of Life
entries: Starting at 10th level, you can use the power of the oceans to rejuvenate your allies. As an action, you can grant one creature inside your Tidal Aura an amount of temporary hit points equal to your druid level.

Any remaining temporary hit points granted by this ability disappear when you use this ability again. Alternatively, you can use your action to stabilize a living creature within your Tidal Aura that has 0 hit points.

subclassFeature.name: Master of the Waves
entries: At 14th level, your bond with the waters of the world has reached its crest. You can cast the {@spell control water} spell at will, without expending a spell slot, provided you target a body of water that is at least a cube of 50 feet on a side or more.
In addition, the radius of your Tidal Aura increases to 30 feet, and other creatures treat the area of your Tidal Aura as difficult terrain even if they have a swimming speed.

subclassFeature.name: Vanguard
entries: Some say the best offense is a good defense, and this couldn't be more true for a vanguard. Such fighters learn to use their shields as a weapon as well as protection. Vanguards learn to protect those around them in surprising and creative ways.

Quite popular amongst dwarves, many mountain clans are known to maintain a number of highly-trained soldiers outfitted with two shields with wicked spikes. That being said, many creative blacksmiths, learned adventurers, and inventive soldiers are known to practice this style of fighting. Even amongst themselves, many vanguards express distinct styles of their art.

subclassFeature.name: Reflexive Defense
entries: Starting when you choose this archetype at 3rd level, you learn to shield your allies. You learn either the {@optfeature Interception|TCE} or {@optfeature Protection|PHB} fighting style, your choice.
Additionally, your affinity for using shields has granted you great speed in equipping them. You can don or doff a shield as a free action on your turn.

subclassFeature.name: Aegis Technique
entries: At 3rd level, you learn to wield a shield as an extension of your body, both as protection as well as a tool. Choose one of the following techniques: {@optfeature juggernaut|SCOE}, {@optfeature sentinel|SCOE}, or {@optfeature twin-guard|SCOE}. Each technique grants you a defensive, offensive, and utility ability.
Whenever you reach a level in this class that grants the Ability Score Improvement feature, you can replace your chosen technique with another one.

subclassFeature.name: Answer The Call
entries: Beginning at 7th level, you've learned that no ally should fight alone. As a bonus action, you can move up to half your walking speed toward a friendly creature that you can see without provoking opportunity attacks. You must end this movement closer to the creature than where you started.

subclassFeature.name: Courageous Spirit
entries: Also at 7th level, your bravery inspires those around you. You and creatures of your choice within 10 feet of you have advantage on saving throws against being {@condition frightened} while you are conscious.

subclassFeature.name: Aegis Adept
entries: At 10th level you have become an expert at utilizing your shield's technique. You gain one of the following benefits, based on your Aegis Technique.

entries.name: Juggernaut
entries: If you move at least 10 feet in a straight line right before bashing a creature with your shield, your attack deals an additional {@dice 1d8} damage on a hit. The traget must then succeed on a Strength saving throw (DC 8 + your proficiency bonus + your Strength modifier) or be knocked {@condition prone}.

entries.name: Sentinel
entries: When you protect a creature using the {@optfeature Protection|PHB} or {@optfeature Interception|TCE} fighting style, that creature can use its reaction to grab the shield with a free hand and make a ranged attack roll with it against the attacking creature. Whether the attack hits or misses, it returns to your hand at the start of your next turn, provided it can reach you unimpeded.

entries.name: Twin-Guard
entries: When you or a creature within 5 feet of you is attacked, you can use your reaction to switch places with that creature before the attack takes place, provided the creature is willing and isn't {@condition incapacitated}. This movement doesn't provoke opportunity attacks.

subclassFeature.name: Bulwark
entries: Starting at 15th level, your instinctive protection affects creatures all around you. While you are wielding a shield, you and all creatures within 5 feet of you gain a +1 bonus to AC.

subclassFeature.name: Aegis Master
entries: By 18th level, your use of a shield is unmatched. While you are wielding a shield, you gain the following benefits:

items: Opportunity attacks made against you are always made at disadvantage.

When an ally within 5 feet of you fails a Strength, Dexterity, or Constitution saving throw, you can expend a use of your Indomitable feature to let the creature reroll the saving throw. The creature must use the new roll.
Whenever you use your Indomitable feature, roll a {@dice d4}. On a 4, you do not expend a use of that feature.

subclassFeature.name: Way of the Five Forms
entries: You belong to a monastic tradition that emphasizes your ki as a connection to instinct, ferocity, and the natural order. The ancient sages and martial artists who shaped your tradition described the stances and strikes with various animals of the natural world.

Monasteries who follow the way of the five forms are typically close communities that constantly watch over each other like animals in a pack. It is customary for masters of this discipline to be knowledgeable in all of the animal astances; they strive to become perfect examples of the versatility of nature. At your option, you can pick from or roll on the Way of the Five Forms Quirks table to create a quirk for your character.

entries.caption: Way of the Five Forms Quirks
rows: You refuse to eat cooked meat, preferring it raw.
You sleep incredibly lightly, ready to wake up and pounce at a moment's notice.
You grow excessive hair on your face and arms.
You feel at home in high up places, and staying close to the ground tends to make you anxious.
You constantly wring your hands and tilt your head.
You like to eat bugs, even picking them from your companion's hair or fur. It's not that weird.

subclassFeature.name: Wild at Heart
entries: When you choose this tradition at 3rd level, you gain proficiency in the {@skill Animal Handling} skill. Additionally, you learn to cast the {@spell speak with animals} spell as a ritual, using Wisdom as your spellcasting ability.

subclassFeature.name: Initiate of the Forms
entries: At 3rd level, you've meditated on the ebb and flow of animal life around you, learning to imitate their movements. Choose two of the following animal styles: Crane, Mantis, Monkey, Snake, and Tiger. You gain the ability to enter the stance of your chosen styles, listed below. Your choices grant you additional benefits as you gain levels in this class.

As a bonus action, you can spend 1 ki point to enter the stance of one animal style you have learned. This stance lasts for 1 minute, and it ends early if you are knocked {@condition unconscious}, you enter another stance, or if you end it on your turn (no action required).

entries.name: Crane
entries: While you are in this stance, you can use Step of the Wind without expending a ki point.

entries.name: Mantis
entries: While you are in this stance and a creature within 5 feet of you makes a melee attack, you can use your reaction to make an unarmed strike against that creature.

entries.name: Monkey
entries: While in this stance, you can use your {@skill Acrobatics} modifier in place of your {@skill Athletics} modifier when making a {@action Grapple} check, and if you are grappling a creature, you may use Flurry of Blows without expending a ki point, provided those are made attacks against the {@condition grappled} creature.

entries.name: Snake
entries: While in this stance, you can use Patient Defense without expending a ki point. You can do so only if you haven't moved more than half your walking speed on your turn, and after you use Patient Defense, your remaining walking speed is halved until the end of the current turn.

entries.name: Tiger
entries: While you are in this stance and you are not wearing armor or using a shield, you gain a +1 bonus to your AC.
Whenever you reach a level in this class that grants the Ability Score Improvement feature, you can replace an animal style you've learned with another animal style you don't already know.

subclassFeature.name: Disciple of the Forms
entries: Beginning at 6th level, your animalistic tendencies strengthen. You gain the following abilities based on your chosen animal styles, whether you are in an animal stance or not:

entries.name: Crane
entries: When a creature you can see hits you with an attack, you can use your reaction to gain resistance to the triggering damage.

entries.name: Mantis
entries: Once per turn, when you miss a creature with an unarmed strike, you can reroll the attack.

entries.name: Monkey
entries: Creatures have disadvantage on opportunity attacks made against you, and you gain a climbing speed equal to your walking speed.

entries.name: Snake
entries: Whenever you use your Stunning Strike feature, you deal additional poison damage to the target equal to your Wisdom modifier (minimum of 1 poison damage).

entries.name: Tiger
entries: When you hit a creature with an unarmed strike, you can spend 1 ki point to deal additional slashing damage to the creature equal to one roll of your Martial Arts die.

subclassFeature.name: Wild Spirit
entries: At 11th level, your connection to your animalistic self deepens. You learn a third animal style, and you gain the following abilities based on your chosen animal styles.

entries.name: Crane
entries: While you are in Crane stance, you have a flying speed equal to half your walking speed. This benefit works only in short bursts; you fall if you end your turn in the air and nothing else is holding you aloft.

entries.name: Mantis
entries: While you are in Mantis stance, making an unarmed strike does not consume your reaction, though you can only make one unarmed strike per turn.

entries.name: Monkey
entries: While you are in Monkey stance, whenever you use the Extra Attack feature to attack twice, you can instead attack three times if all the attacks are unarmed strikes or {@action Grapple} checks.

entries.name: Snake
entries: While you are in Snake stance, the range of your unarmed strikes is 5 feet greater than normal on your turn.

entries.name: Tiger
entries: While you are in Tiger stance, your unarmed strikes deal additional damage equal to your Strength modifier (minimum +1 damage).

subclassFeature.name: Master of the Forms
entries: Beginning at 17th level, you learn to blend your animal styles fluidly, even leading to animalistic transformations. Whenever you enter an animal stance, you may enter two stances at the same time, gaining the benefits of both.

Additionally, as an action, you can spend 3 ki points to cast {@spell polymorph} on yourself, becoming one of the creatures associated with your chosen animal styles: Crane (using the {@creature Giant Eagle|MM} statblock, except your size is Medium), Mantis (using the {@creature Giant Spider|MM} statblock, except your size is Tiny), Monkey (using the {@creature Ape|MM} statblock), Snake (using the {@creature Jaculi|ToA} statblock, except your size is Small), or Tiger (using the {@creature Tiger|MM} statblock). While you are transformed, you can enter that animal's stance without expending a ki point, you use your Martial Arts die for your melee attacks, and you can make two attacks on your turn when you take the {@action Attack} action, regardless of whether your statblock has the Multiattack action.
Once you cast {@spell polymorph} using this feature, you can't do so again until you finish a short or long rest.

subclassFeature.name: Way of the Great Oak
entries: Monastaries that follow the way of the flowering vine tend to be reclusive and anchorite, its members more likely than not observing vows of silence and fasting. Such monks revere great, ancient trees, seeing the immense strength in their unwavering fortitude. Any slight to the glorious flora surrounding them is taken as a personal offense, and if one of their sacred trees was ever felled, these monks will often use this hard bark as protective armor, swearing vengeance on whatever force dared destroy such a beautiful testament to life.

subclassFeature.name: Bonus Proficiencies
entries: When you choose this tradition at 3rd level, you treat natural armor as a second skin. You gain proficiency with the {@skill Nature} skill. You also gain proficiency with light and medium armor.

subclassFeature.name: Natural Defense
entries: Also at 3rd level, you learn to align your ki with the spirits that inhabit the living tissue in your armor, becoming one with its protective skin. Whenever you finish a short or long rest, you can touch one set of light or medium armor that isn't made of metal and focus your ki on it. While you are wearing this armor, you gain the following benefits until you use this feature again:

items: You can use your Wisdom modifier in place of your Dexterity modifier to calculate your AC.
You can use Martial Arts and Unarmored Movement even while you are wearing this armor.

You can cast the {@spell druidcraft} and {@spell thorn whip} cantrips. Additionally, as an action, you can spend 1 ki point to cast the {@spell entangle} spell. Wisdom is your spellcasting ability for these spells.

subclassFeature.name: Rooted in Place
entries: At 6th level, you can plant yourself in the ground, becoming remarkably resilient. You have advantage on saving throws made to resist being knocked {@condition prone} or moved against your will.

subclassFeature.name: Strong Limbs
entries: Also at 6th level, you learn to harden your skin, growing a bark-like layer on your hands and feet. As a bonus action, you can spend 1 ki point to harden your limbs for 1 minute. For the duration, when you make an unarmed strike, your damage die increases to a {@dice d8}. The damage die for this feature increases again when you reach certain levels in this class: to a {@dice d10} at 11th level and a {@dice d12} at 17th level.

subclassFeature.name: Heart of Oak
entries: At 11th level, whenever you are hit by a melee attack, you can use your reaction to spend 1 ki point to attempt to reduce the damage you take by {@dice 1d10} + your Constitution modifier + half your monk level.
If you reduce the damage to 0, you can make an unarmed strike against the attacking creature as part of the same reaction, provided it is within range.

subclassFeature.name: Paragon of Nature
entries: At 17th level, your presence sings life into the world around you. Whenever you walk, vibrant patches of grass, flowers, and fungi follow your path. You can supress this effect at any time, no action required, and any plant life created this way fades within 1 hour.

Additionally, your body becomes protected from corruption, such as a snake's venom or the {@spell contagion} spell. When you are subjected to an effect that allows you to make a Constitution saving throw to take only half damage, you instead take no damage if you succeed on the saving throw, and only half damage if you fail.

subclassFeature.name: Way of the Weave
entries: Through countless hours of meditation, monks who follow the Way of the Weave are able to form a connection to the arcane energy of the world, allowing them to will their ki into spells. These monks are known as Weavers, powerful practitioners of magic who blend martial arts and spellcasting to elicit devastating effect. Such monks specialize in the schools of divination and transmutation magic. They use divination magic to peer into the expansive knowledge of the Weave, and transmutation magic to alter their bodies and the world around them to meet any threat they may face.

subclassFeature.name: Spellcasting
entries: Starting when you choose this tradition at 3rd level, you form a connection to arcane energy, allowing you to shape a portion of your ki into spells.

entries.name: Cantrips
entries: You learn two cantrips of your choice from the {@filter wizard spell list|spells|level=0|subclass=Monk: Weave (SCOE)}. You learn an additional wizard cantrip of your choice at 10th level.

entries.name: Spell Slots
entries: The Way of the Weave Spellcasting table shows how many spell slots you have to cast your spells of 1st level and higher. To cast one of these spells, you must expend a slot of the spell's level or higher. You regain all expended spell slots when you finish a long rest.
For example, if you know the 1st-level spell {@spell feather fall} and have a 1st-level and a 2nd-level spell slot available, you can cast {@spell feather fall} using either slot.

entries.name: Spells Known of 1st-Level and Higher
entries: You know three 1st-level wizard spells of your choice, two of which you must choose from the divination and transmutation spells on the wizard spell list.

The Spells Known column of the Way of the Weave Spellcasting table shows when you learn more wizard spells of 1st level or higher. Each of these spells must be a divination or transmutation spell of your choice, and must be of a level for which you have spell slots. For instance, when you reach 7th level in this class, you can learn one new spell of 1st or 2nd level.
The spells you learn at 8th, 14th, and 20th level can come from any school of magic.

Whenever you gain a level in this class, you can replace one of the wizard spells you know with another spell of your choice from the wizard spell list. The new spell must be of a level for which you have spell slots, and it must be a divination or transmutation spell, unless you're replacing the spell you gained at 3rd, 8th, 14th, or 20th level, which can be from any school of magic.

entries.name: Spellcasting Ability
entries: Wisdom is your spellcasting ability for your wizard spells, since you learned your spells through deep meditation on the aspects of the Weave. You use your Wisdom whenever a spell refers to your spellcasting ability. In addition, you use your Wisdom modifier when setting the saving throw DC for a wizard spell you cast and when making an attack roll with one.

subclassFeature.name: Elegant Weapon
entries: At 3rd level, you learn to focus the magical energy around you into a weapon of your choice, turning it into a conduit for your arcane abilities. Whenever you use your Dedicated Weapon feature, you gain the following additional benefits while wielding that weapon:

items: The weapon deals force damage instead of its normal damage type.
You can use your Wisdom modifier, instead of Strength or Dexterity modifier, for the attack and damage rolls you make with this weapon.
You can use the weapon as a spellcasting focus for your wizard spells.

subclassFeature.name: Fighting Foresight
entries: At 6th level, you can concentrate on the Weave, sensing a creature's movements before they happen. As a bonus action, you give yourself advantage on your next melee attack roll on the current turn.

Seeing the Weave in such a way requires intense focus; you can use this bonus action only if you haven't moved during this turn, and after you use the bonus action, your speed becomes 0 until the end of the current turn.

subclassFeature.name: Flowing Defense
entries: Beginning at 11th level, you learn to control the ebb and flow of magic directed toward you. When you are the target of a ranged spell attack, you can use your reaction to deflect or even catch the spell. If the spell has multiple ranged spell attacks, you can only catch or deflect one of them. When you do so, the damage you take from the attack is reduced by {@dice 1d10} + your Wisdom modifier + your monk level.

If you reduce the damage to 0 and one of your hands is free or holding your Elegant Weapon, you can seize control of the spell. If you do, you can spend 1 ki point per level of the seized spell (minimum of 1) to make a ranged spell attack as part of the same reaction. You use your Wisdom modifier for this ranged attack and the resulting damage, if relevant.

subclassFeature.name: Grasp of the Weave
entries: Also at 11th level, you can connect more deeply to creatures and objects around you through the Weave, even learning to manipulate them. You can spend 5 ki points to cast the {@spell telekinesis} spell.
Once you use this feature, you can't use it again until you finish a short or long rest.

subclassFeature.name: Master of Mind and Spirit
entries: At 17th level, your practied connection to the Weave grants you the power to freely shape the form of your ki into spells. You can use your ki points to gain additional spell slots.

entries.name: Creating Spell Slots
entries: As a bonus action, you can transform unexpended ki points into one spell slot. The Creating Spell Slots table below shows the cost of creating a spell slot of any given level. Any spell slot you create with this feature vanishes when you finish a short or long rest.

subclassFeature.name: Oath of the Open Sea
entries: The Oath of the Open Sea calls to sea-faring warriors, swashbuckling sailors, and journeying guardians who seek the thrill of an endless horizon. Driven to seek the adventure and mystery across and beneath every endless oceanic expanse, paladins who swear this oath stand against those who would deny the liberties afforded to like-minded travelers, rooting out the tyrannical and corrupt that claim any shore.

Such guardians believe in the natural beauty of the sea, often making offerings and prayers to entities or deities that influence safe passage, while often feeling called to hunt those monstrosities that seek to terrorize and spoil the waters with wanton violence and ill intent.

entries.subclassFeature: Tenets of the Open Sea|Paladin|PHB|Open Sea|SCOE|3

subclassFeature.name: Tenets of the Open Sea
entries: Freedom can be a selfless virtue or a selfish want. For paladins who swear the Oath of the Open Sea, freedom is the highest calling, and a gift to be granted to all.

entries.name: Adapt
entries: The waters of the ocean can shift around any obstacle, or become an impassable one. To embrace this fluidity is to be ready for any challenge.

entries.name: Live Free
entries: All should be free to chart their own path without oppression, and be careful to not become this oppression.

entries.name: Chart the Uncharted
entries: The world is filled with mystery. Uncover those who would hide their dark deeds in shadow, and find the path to becoming something great.

entries.name: Trust the Skies
entries: Nature is a source of portent and council that should be heeded.

subclassFeature.name: Oath Spells
entries: You gain oath spells at the paladin levels listed in the Oath of the Open Sea Spells table. See the Sacred Oath class feature hor how oath spells work.

entries.caption: Oath of the Open Sea Spells

subclassFeature.name: Channel Divinity
entries: When you take this oath at 3rd level, you gain the following two Channel Divinity options.

entries.name: Fury of the Tides
entries: As a bonus action, you can use your Channel Divinity to channel the powerful might of the waves to bolster your attacks for 1 minute. For the duration, each of your weapon attacks deals an additional {@dice 1d6} bludgeoning damage. Additionally, once on each of your turns when you hit a Large or smaller creature with a weapon attack, you can choose to push the target up to 10 feet away from you.

entries.name: Sea Spray
entries: As an action, you can use your Channel Divinity to create an aura of thick fog, obscuring the area around you. A cloud of fog extends 20 feet from you in every direction, creating a heavily obscured area. You and creatures within 5 feet of you treat this area as lightly obscured. This fog lasts for 10 minutes, it spreads around corners, and it cannot be dispersed.

subclassFeature.name: Aura of Liberation
entries: Beginning at 7th level, the sea keeps you and your allies' movements spry. You and creatures of your choice within 10 feet of you ignore the normal penalties of underwater movement and attacks. Additionally, each creature in your area can spend 5 feet of movement to automatically escape a grapple or nonmagical restraints.
At 18th level, the range of this aura increases to 30 feet.

subclassFeature.name: Stormy Waters
entries: Starting at 15th level, whenever a creature enters or exists your melee range, you can use your reaction to call crashing waters on your attacker. The creature takes {@dice 1d12} bludgeoning damage and must succeed on a Strength saving throw or be knocked {@condition prone}.

subclassFeature.name: Mythic Swashbuckler
entries: By 20th level, you have become a paragon of heroic adventure. As an action, you channel the spirits of historic sea captains, gaining the following benefits for 1 minute:

items: You have advantage on Strength checks and Strength saving throws.
You have advantage on all Dexterity saving throws against effects that you can see.
You can take the {@action Dodge} action as a bonus action.

If you are within 5 feet of a creature and no other creatures are within 5 feet of a creature and no other creatures are within 5 feet of you, you have advantage on your attacks against that creature.

entries: Once you use this feature, you can't use it again until you finish a long rest, unless you expend a 5th-level spell slot to use it again.

subclassFeature.name: Oath of Revelry
entries: Those who take the Oath of Revelry value pleasure and beauty above all else. Such paladins are often avid hedonists, believing personal pleasure and satisfaction to be the most moral path. Such believers see great error in the path of altruism, which often leads creatures to bring upon the very things they seek to prevent; this causes great suffering to everyone around a creature and, even worse, to themselves.

Some keepers of this oath can be found as guests in a king's court, while others might travel the world and experience everything life has to offer. They will often entice others to pursue such luxuries with enchantments, illusions, and good-old fashioned charm.

Not all such paladins are such bons vivants, however; some serve darker agendas. Making a pact with a dark deity is not uncommon, especially in pursuit of one's own perfection. They use their powers to corrupt others by twisting their desires and dreams into acts of violence and self-destruction.

Regardless of their intentions, the Oath of Revelry leads creatures to experience as much pleasure in life as possible; destroying your enemies should bring as much elation as the celebrations of your victories.

subclassFeature.name: Tenets of Revelry
entries: Though the details of the oath might vary from creature to creature, the main principles stay the same.

entries.name: Pursue Your Dreams
entries: Let nothing stop you from living life to the fullest, not even your own self-doubt.

entries.name: Become the Muse
entries: Help others fulfill their desires, whatever they may be. However, never do so by sacrificing your own pleasure; they're not worth it.

entries.name: Beauty is Perfection
entries: Beauty is the spark of desire and the fire of pleasure. Always strive for physical perfection and settle for nothing less.

entries.name: Pain is a Scourge
entries: If you have those in your care, protect them from pain. Exact it upon your enemies instead, for those who fail to appreciate your beauty are not worthy of the pleasures of life.

subclassFeature.name: Oath Spells
entries: You gain oath spells at the paladin levels listed in the Oath of Revelry Spells table. See the Sacred Oath class feature for how oath spells work.

subclassFeature.name: Channel Divinity
entries: When you take this oath at 3rd level, you gain the following two Channel Divinity options.

entries.name: Alluring Presence
entries: As a bonus action, you can use your Channel Divinity to become the center of attention. Your voice, appearance, and disposition becomes far more appealing to creatures within 30 feet of you that can see or hear you. For the next hour, you have advantage on all Charisma checks made to interact with creatures within range, and these creatures have disadvantage on Charisma ({@skill Deception}) checks made against you.

entries.name: Blinding Violence
entries: You can use your Channel Divinity to tap into a creature's most violent desires and exploit them, sparking a fit of brutal rage. As a bonus action, choose a creature you can see within 60 feet of you to make a Wisdom saving throw. The creature must already be engaged in combat. On a failed save, the target must immediately move up to half of its movement speed and make a melee attack against the closest available target. A creature can willingly fail this saving throw if it chooses.

subclassFeature.name: Aura of Captivation
entries: By 7th level, you effortlessly appear immaculate, you constantly seem to smell nice, and even wounds and scars only make you appear hardier. Creatures within 10 feet of you have disadvantage on saving throws against your illusion and enchantment spells.
At 18th level, the range of this aura increases to 30 feet.

subclassFeature.name: Ultimate Self
entries: Starting at 15th level, your body is a perfected temple—no creature can defil your most holy of places. You have advantage on saving throws against being {@condition charmed}, {@condition petrified}, {@condition poisoned}, or cursed, and you are immune to any spell ore ffect that would alter your form against your will.

subclassFeature.name: Majestic Grace
entries: At 20th level, you finally reach the peak of perfection, granting you the following benefits:

items: You may add your Charisma modifier to damage rolls of your weapon attacks (minimum +1).
Whenever you make a Charisma check, you can treat a {@dice d20} roll of 9 or lower as a 10.
Creatures that are {@condition charmed} by you do not immeditely turn hostile when a spell or effect expires.

entries: If you become {@condition incapacitated} or die, your image of perfection falters, and you lose these benfits until you finish a long rest.

subclassFeature.name: Oath of Providence
entries: Paladins who take the Oath of Providence see the ebb and flow of the strings of fate around them, regardless of what others call it: destiny, luck, or the Weave. They understand that these countless choices lead one down the path of their creation.

Tyrants, warlords, corrupt officials, and any others who seek to rob otehrs from the freedom of choice the sworn foes of these Paladins. These paladins are the executioners. Their oath gives them the power to blend destiny in their favor and send foes to their final fate.

subclassFeature.name: Tenets of Providence
entries: The tenets of the Oath of Providence are written in stone on the tombs of paladins undertaking this path.

entries.name: Welcome Adversity
entries: When bad luck comes your way, understand it was meant to be and search for the opportunity fate has given you within your loss.

entries.name: Deliver Enemies to Fate
entries: Those who mettle with destiny and forgo the natural order are enemies of fate. They must die by your hand.

entries.name: Accept that which Cannot Change
entries: Fate is a force more powerful than the gods. Accept that there are situations in which you're powerless, and take control over that which you can influence.

subclassFeature.name: Oath Spells
entries: You gain oath spells at the paladin levels listed in the Oath of Providence Spells table. See the Sacred Oath class feature for how oath spells work.

subclassFeature.name: Channel Divinity
entries: When you take this oath at 3rd level, you gain the following two Channel Divinity options.

entries.name: Predestined Mercy
entries: As a reaction when you or a creature you can see within 60 feet of you makes a saving throw against a damaging effect, you can use your Channel Divinity to peer into the near future, tempting fate into a favorable outcome. If the target would take half damage on a successful saving throw, it instead takes no damage, and only half as much damage on a failed one.

entries.name: Kiss of Calamity
entries: As an action, you can use your Channel Divinity to besiege an enemy with bad luck. Choose one creature of your choice within 30 feet of you to make a Charisma saving throw against your spell save DC. On a failed save, the target has disadvantage on all saving throws it makes for 1 minute. This effect ends if you call {@condition unconscious}.

subclassFeature.name: Aura of Favor
entries: Beginning at 7th level, your good fortune guides your hand. Whenever you or creatures of your choice within 10 feet of you regain hit points, treat any dice rolled to determine the hit points regained as having rolled their maximum value.
At 18th level, the range of this aura increases to 30 feet.

subclassFeature.name: Gift of Foresight
entries: Starting at 15th level, you are able to see the imminent movements of creatures and objects all around you as vague, shadowy visions. You cannot be surprised while you are conscious, and you have advantage on all initiative rolls.

subclassFeature.name: Hand of Fate
entries: At 20th level, you become an agent of destiny, guiding the outcome of the events all around you. When a creature targets you with an attack or a harmful spell, it must first make a Wisdom saving throw against your spell save DC. On a failed save, the creature must choose a new target or lose the attack or spell. This effect doesn't protect you from area effects, such as the explosion of a {@spell fireball}.
As soon as a creature damages you, it is immune to this effect for 24 hours.

subclassFeature.name: Oath of Treachery
entries: The Oath of Treachery is the path followed by paladins who care only for their own power and survival. Such warriors have felt the pain of treachery so often that it has become central to their worldview. They are faithful only to their own wants and needs, and will deceive out of the anticipation of deceit, caught in a seemingly endless cycle.

Not all paladins of this oath trick their allies so readily, however. Instead, they are valued tacticians, being both excellent liars and intuitive as magic users; it is quite difficult to mislead someone who is constantly on guard against such schemes, lies, and illusions.

subclassFeature.name: Tenets of Treachery
entries: First and foremost, any paladin who embraces the Oath of Treachery believes they owe allegiance to no one, and that the very idea of allegiance is optimistic at best.

entries.name: Me
entries: Power is safety, and it belongs to me; the only person I can trust with power is...

entries.name: Myself
entries: If others seem useful to me, I will align myself with them. But, like all the rest, they will most likely turn on me...

entries.name: And I
entries: ... will have to betray them before they can betray me. It is only a matter of time.

subclassFeature.name: Oath Spells
entries: You gain oath spells at the paladin levels listed in the Oath of Treachery Spells table. See the Sacred Oath class feature for how oath spells work.

subclassFeature.name: Channel Divinity
entries: When you take this oath at 3rd level, you gain the following two Channel Divinity options.

entries.name: Dark Reflection
entries: You can use your Channel Divinity to step into the darkness of your own shadow and out of another creature's. As a bonus action, you teleport up to 30 feet to an unoccupied space within 5 feet of another creature that you can see. You may make a melee weapon attack against the target as part of this bonus action.

entries.name: Uncover Secrets
entries: As an action, you can use your Channel Divinity to imbue your eyes with the power to uproot hidden mysteries around you. For 1 hour, you can see normally in darkness, both magical and nonmagical, to a distance of 60 feet. If you already have {@sense darkvision}, this distance instead increases by 60 feet. Additionally, you can see {@condition invisible} creatures within 10 feet of you for the duration.

subclassFeature.name: Aura of Vigilance
entries: By 7th level, you are constantly wary of an attack, able to react quickly while you aren't restricted. When a creature you can see within 10 feet of you hits you with an attack, you can reduce the damage you take by an amount equal to {@dice 1d4} + your proficiency bonus (to a minimum of 0 damage). You must not be wearing heavy armor in order to use this ability.
At 18th level, the range of this aura increases to 30 feet, and you cannot be surprised while you are conscious.

subclassFeature.name: Takes One to Know One
entries: Starting at 15th level, you are so familiar with deceit that you are able to see through almost any ruse. You have advantage on saving throws against illusions, and whenever you make a Wisdom ({@skill Insight}) or Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) check, you can treat a {@dice d20} roll of 9 or lower as a 10.

subclassFeature.name: Icon of Deception
entries: At 20th level, you begin to emanate feelings of treachery, able to direct them at your enemies. As an action, you can magically transform into an avatar of deceit, gaining the following benefits for 1 minute:

items: You can use your bonus action to become {@condition invisible}. This invisibility ends when you take an action or a reaction while you are in an area of bright light.
If you have advantage on an attack roll, you gain a bonus to the damage roll equal to your Charisma bonus (minimum +1).

When a creature hits you with an attack, it must make a Wisdom saving throw against your spell save DC. On a failed save, you choose what it does for its action during its next turn, though you cannot make the target willingly harm itself. The target automatically succeeds this saving throw if it is immune to being {@condition charmed}.

entries: Once you use this feature, you can't use it again until you finish a long rest, unless you expend a 5th-level spell slot to use it again.
